newsitem.title: USA: U.S. mortgage-backeds edge higher ahead of holiday.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mortgage-backeds edge higher ahead of holiday.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backed securities inched higher in pre-holiday trade on Friday and higher-coupon spreads narrowed considerably to comparable Treasuries, market experts said.
But traders said pass-through spreads should widen out in the next few trading sessions.
"We are not going to stay this tight," said one mortgage trader at an investment firm in New York, adding that spreads "will widen a couple of ticks next week," due to their current "over-tightness."
Mortgage-backed market players were mostly quiet, anticipating an early departure for a long holiday weekend.
PSA The Bond Market Trade Association recommended an early close -- 1400 EDT/1800 GMT -- for U.S. credit markets on Friday and a full close on Monday for Memorial Day.
"It's just been dead today," one head Ginnie trader said. "We're only one basis point tighter today -- it's the worst day of the week," he added.
In pass-throughs, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.5-percent coupons were up 3/32 at 99-12/32, yielding 95 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note.
Comparable Fannie Mae paper was up 4/32 at 99-13/32, and Freddie Mac issues were 2/32 higher at 99-17/32.
In late trading, the five-year note was up 1/32 at 6.58 percent, while the 10-year note was up 3/32 to yield 6.74 percent.
